repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance (FSTA) Project for Azerbaijan were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible; the Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: A broad definition of the
            disbursement categories contributes to project flexibility
            and facilitates the movement of fund without difficult
            formal reallocations. Excluding the 'Unallocated'
            funds, the FSTA project had only three disbursement
            categories. This breakdown facilitated the addition of new
            activities, and the switching of funds targeted for one
            activity to without being subject to lengthy change
            procedures, either in Azerbaijan or in the Bank. Important
            synergies can be realized through good cooperation between
            the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Bank. During
            project preparation, Bank and IMF staff worked as one team
            both in the elaboration of the strategy and the design of
            the technical assistance needed to implement the strategy.
            Throughout implementation, the IMF both continued to support
            the program and provided advisory services (especially
            relating to the payments system architecture) that
            complemented the International Development Agency (IDA)
            funded assistance and Bank team. This close collaboration
            was an important factor in the initial and sustained strong
            commitment to the banking sector reform strategy, as well as
            in the successful outcome of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Project will assist the Government of Azerbaijan
            implement, and develop its financial sector strategy,
            through a technical assistance (TA) focused on bank
            restructuring, and divestiture, and, by enhancing banking
            infrastructure, and supervision. The main components will:
            1) provide advisory services to the United Universal Joint
            Stock Bank (BUSbank) in strengthening, and improving its
            organization, and operation. It includes a foreign advisor
            to provide TA in the transformation of the Agroprom Bank
            into Agrarcredit, a non-bank credit institution, in addition
            to overseeing the privatization of the BUSbank. A resident
            advisor will supervise the bank's managerial/prudential
            activities, while short-term advisors, and consultants will
            assist in the implementation of new international accounting
            standards, and, in information technology, and management
            information systems; 2) strengthen the capacity of the
            Azerbaijan National Bank (ANB), supported by advisory
            services in its strategy formulation, banking supervision,
            and infrastructure. Funds will be provided for
            hardware/software, needed to finalize implementation of the
            payment system reform, and, for the expansion of ANB's
            general ledger system; and, 3) provide project management,
            and administration support, through procurement advisors,
            while incremental operating costs will also be financed.
